items.title: Labor's hate laws pass despite a divided Coalition
items.description: The federal government has passed new laws targeting hate groups with support from the Liberals, despite a last-ditch effort from the Nationals to make further amendments.

items.title: NSW's first female governor Dame Marie Bashir dies aged 95
items.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns says a state funeral will be held for the veteran public servant, who he describes as "an extraordinary Australian".

items.title: British-born Aussies giving up UK citizenship over new passport rules
items.description: Frustrated dual British-Australian citizens are weighing up their options in response to new passport rules. Here's why some are letting go of their British citizenship.

items.title: Massive Chinese embassy in London approved despite 'nest of spies' concerns
items.description: The new embassy will sit in the city's Royal Mint Court alongside London's famous financial hub, despite experts and human rights groups raising concerns about foreign interference.

items.title: David Beckham breaks silence after son Brooklyn cuts ties
items.description: The football superstar told broadcasters at the World Economic Forum that "children are allowed to make mistakes" in his first public comments since his son's allegations went public.

items.title: 'He's a T-Rex': Newsom tells US allies 'stand united' against Trump amid Greenland crisis
items.description: As European leaders struggle to come up with ways to ease the US president's ambition for a take over of Greenland, a prominent Democrat is accusing them of "rolling over".

items.title: Woolies' new AI system fundamentally changes the role of the shopper
items.description: Without scrutiny, agent-led shopping risks quietly reconfiguring consumer behaviour in ways that are difficult to detect — and even harder to reverse.

items.title: Israel starts demolishing former UN aid agency headquarters
items.description: The UN has labelled Israel's move to bulldoze a former UNRWA headquarters a  "serious violation of international law".

items.title: Osaka brings fashion to the court as plucky Aussies progress to second round
items.description: Seeing Naomi Osaka don a jellyfish-inspired outfit was one highlight of day three of the tournament, however two plucky Australians — Dane Sweeny and James Duckworth also put on a show.

items.title: Baby killer Lucy Letby to face no further criminal charges
items.description: The UK's Crown Prosecution Service says it considered the offences of murder or attempted murder in relation to the deaths of nine babies.

items.title: Kim Jong Un fires vice premier describing him as 'a goat yoked to pull an ox cart'
items.description: The North Korean leader blamed Yang Sun Ho for "confusion" and cost blow-outs at a factory project in the country's north-east.

items.title: What we know about the four NSW shark attacks in 48 hours
items.description: Four shark attacks are documented within 48 hours at beaches across New South Wales, lifting the anxieties of swimmers and surfers who are considering a dip in the ocean.

items.title: 'Wasn't I smart': Hanson celebrates historic rise in polls
items.description: While she's made no secret of her desire to eventually unseat Anthony Albanese, the One Nation leader's immediate electoral strategy is to gain ground at upcoming state elections.

items.title: Son of Norwegian princess faces new charges, including drug offence
items.description: Marius Borg Høiby faces six new charges including an alleged "serious narcotics offence" in addition to sexual assault charges.

items.title: 'Massive impact': Midnight Oil founder and drummer Rob Hirst dies aged 70
items.description: Rob Hirst was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in 2023.

items.title: What is Trump's Board of Peace and why could it be a threat to the UN?
items.description: Donald Trump appears to be trying to build his own international peacekeeping body, which he calls the "Board of Peace". Here's why experts think it might attempt to rival the UN.

items.title: Brooklyn Beckham has cut ties with his famous parents. What can we learn from it?
items.description: Celebrity family rifts are not new. Experts weigh in on how they can spark negative feelings about our own family dynamics.

items.title: What couples get wrong when worrying about how much sex they're having
items.description: Whether it's TV shows or what our friends say, we pick up an idea of "normal" sex frequency from lots of places. But experts say how often you've having sex doesn't tell you much about whether it's satisfying or enjoyable.

items.title: Viral lookout inundated by thousands of daily visitors set to close
items.description: A council will shut an iconic Blue Mountains cliff after being overrun with tourists, sparking serious safety and environmental concerns.

items.title: MPs can still take partners, kids on work trips under new family travel rules
items.description: Politicians can still charge taxpayers for taking their partners and children on work-related trips outside Canberra under tighter new rules set independently.

items.title: Canadian teenager Piper James named as woman found dead on K'gari
items.description: The woman was found surrounded by dingoes after going for an early-morning swim.

items.title: 'Large bull camels weighing hundreds of kilos' move into NT communities
items.description: Hundreds of large bull camels descend on remote communities in Central Australia, causing damage to infrastructure in their search for water and prompting calls for federal assistance.

items.title: Climate change triggers 'remarkable response' from Antarctic penguins
items.description: Penguins in parts of Antarctica are breeding up to two weeks earlier than a decade ago, likely in response to climate change, according to a long-term study.

items.title: Known now for his signature red, it was an ivory wedding dress that brought Valentino fame
items.description: "Valentino red", now synonymous with the Italian designer, was introduced to the world in 1959. But it wasn't until years later he commanded true global attention — and with an entirely different dress.

items.title: Vine lays down marker as Watson wins blistering TDU prologue
items.description: British rider Sam Watson claimed a blisteringly quick Tour Down Under prologue time-trial victory, but Jay Vine took significant time out of his rivals.
